title: Ray Finkelstein backs airports ahead of final PC report
text:
Airports have stepped up pressure on the federal government to ignore airlines' demands for regulation by bringing in former Federal Court Justice Ray Finkelstein to bat on their behalf.

The Honourable Mr Finkelstein, who was president of the Australian Competition Tribunal between 2008 and 2011, has told the federal government that it should stick with the current "light handed" system as it prepares to release a final report on airport regulation from the Productivity Commission.

Airlines' calls for access to commercial arbitration when there are disputes were not necessary nor appropriate, Mr Finkelstein said in a memo that has been sent to the federal government.

"If adopted, a rational airline will refer any controversial issue to arbitration because an award will rarely, if ever, result in a more onerous obligation than would be the product of a negotiated outcome," he said, adding that airlines would typically try arbitration "simply for the chance of doing better."

"The inefficiency of such a scheme goes without saying," he said.

Mr Finkelstein was paid by airports to review the commmission's draft decision.
description: A former Federal Court Justice hired by the airports to review the Productivity Commission's draft report on regulation says he agrees with the airports.
